p: In low population density areas, the livelihoods of people engaged in agriculture, forestry, and fisheries depend directly on the environment. Climate impacts threaten not only their health and safety but also their ability to earn a living (Berkes, 2007; Watts et al., 2015). People in these areas also may have less access to medical care and disaster‐response resources than people in higher‐population‐density areas (Morrow, 1999). In areas with lower population densities, diminishing resources are associated with the privatizing of public services and with limited social‐service delivery, although these trends may vary (Lobao, Adua, & Hooks, 2014).
